choices.C: With a clear end date of 30 November, and a small number of Work Packages, the Project Board should track project progress using individual Team Plans.
choices.B: Progress can be recorded and tracked using the product checklist, with the planned and actual quality management activities captured in the Daily Log.
choices.A: This is an error as a Gantt chart or some form of time line, where actuals will be recorded and tracked against the planned schedule of delivery, is mandatory.

questions.question_text: There is no project schedule in the Project Initiation Documentation. How can project progress be tracked without a schedule to track against?

discussion.content: In this case, with a clear end date and a small number of Work Packages, tracking project progress using individual Team Plans (Option C) makes sense. The Project Managerâ€™s use of the Daily Log to record all risks, issues, lessons, and quality results also provides valuable information for tracking progress and managing the project effectively
Is this the old Prince2 syllabus?

In this scenario, the Project Manager combined the Starting Up a Project process and the Initiating a Project process and produced a simple Project Initiation Documentation (PlO) that did not include a Project Brief. However, the PlO still contains the project definition, which is part of the Project Product Description. The project definition describes what the project must deliver in order to gain acceptance 2. Therefore, the project definition provides a common understanding of the desired outcomes for the prepared calendar pack.

questions.question_text: There is no Project Brief. How can there be a common understanding of the desired outcomes for the prepared calendar pack?

choices.C: The simple Project Initiation Documentation contains the project definition.
choices.B: The Project Brief should have been produced and approved before the project progressed into the initiation stage.
choices.A: The simple Project Initiation Documentation contains the Quality Management Strategy. This contains details of the acceptance criteria for this project.

questions.question_text: There is no mention of any Stage Plans, yet there are two further stages proposed. How will this be resolved?

discussion.content: A. It is appropriate for the Calendar project to be run as two further stages as there is a key decision to be made at the end of stage 2. Stage Plans will be produced.

choices.A: It is appropriate for the Calendar project to be run as two further stages as there is a key decision to be made at the end of stage 2. Stage Plans will be produced.
choices.C: There will be three Stage Plans, the two management stages plus an additional stage to plan and complete the activities of the Closing a Project process.
choices.B: Whilst the activities are divided into two further stages, there is no reason why the Calendar project should use stages. The project will therefore be run as a single stage project and the activities will be added to the Initiation Stage Plan.

questions.question_text: No Benefits Review Plan has been developed. Where should the schedule of benefit reviews be recorded?

discussion.content: Benefit reviews should be planned and recorded in the simple PID.

choices.C: Benefit reviews should be planned and recorded in the simple PID.
choices.A: As deliverables of the project, all benefit reviews should be scheduled and documented in the Project Plan during initiation.
choices.B: Small projects do not require a schedule of benefit reviews as only one review is required towards the end of the project and this should be documented within the Business Case.
